title: Is Lulu evil?
body: Apart from the obvious listing of {{champion:45}}  as a friend on her lore page, she has no problem with turning her opponents into cute fluffy animals before killing them (it's almost as if she prefers it that way). She also doesn't seem to care that pix basically stole her whole life away from her, or that her family is dead. Is it possible she is a sociopath?

replies.body:
When looking at Lulu it's important to consider English fairy tales, particularly those involving the fae realms and things like elves, gnomes, and dwarves. These creatures are not particularly violent or cruel* within the expectations and boundaries of their own society*, but have little understanding or empathy for humans and/or human culture. This isn't because they're evil, it's because they're far removed from humanity as whole. 

Lulu is very much the same way. She doesn't understand that to many, her magic isn't a game - she grew up among the fey, where changing forms and wild magic are extremely common, and where things like audio/visual perception and the concept of death don't necessarily mean the same thing they do to the rest of Runeterra. 

She's not a sociopath. She's a child who never grew up.

I've been a bit curious about the yordles as a faction - there doesn't really seem to be a set consistency to them as a group. Are they techo-crazy, like Heimerdinger and others; or are they rural, like Teemo; or fantasy, like Veigar and Lulu? Of course there's contrasts between champions (yordle champions seem to be more different than most), but how does the race in general do things? Are they unified or are there several different groups of them?
Other factions, like hextechy Piltover, has a consistent theme; what is Bandle City's consistent theme?
Old lore has rural elements, like the new shopkeeper. But then there was a mothership and crazy-techy-what-not. Do you have a set direction for them at this time?

Bandle City has remained largely undefined until very recently - which is why there's a big rocket ship in the middle and the art looks like one of the earlier trading posts in Oregon Trail. Like Targon and Icathia we have traditionally had loose interpretations of what *could* be there, smaller faction-oriented stories and the like, rather than any big-picture stuff. Foundations has been working hard in that regard, rebuilding a vision of Bandle City that plays to the innate strengths of Yordle characters and society. 

What I *can* say is that Yordles, as they have always been, are a eclectic bunch that excel at pretty much anything they set their minds to. But Runeterra still doesn't know very much about them, and whether or not they stand unified in really anything is still a matter of scholarly debate. Why are some inventors and some warriors? Why do some fight and some explore? Why is that very short magician laughing maniacally, and who decided to build a death robot with toilet plunger feet? That whimsy and mystery defines Yordles much more so than any traditional standard, so if you're looking for an overall theme right now, that's probably your best answer.

But Runeterra still doesn't know very much about them, and whether or not they stand unified in really anything is still a matter of scholarly debate. Why are some inventors and some warriors? That whimsy and mystery defines Yordles much more so than any traditional standard, so if you're looking for an overall theme right now, that's probably your best answer.

Because not every member of a race/species acts exactly the same? I know that this is a mistake that most fantasy/sci fi writers make, but I hate when they write off entire races as monolithic entities that act in a certain way. Why do all dwarves carry around axes and drink a lot? Why are all elves in love with nature? Sure, culture means that their society can influence and approve of them acting in stereotypical ways, but it's really annoying to see that sort of thing. I really don't want yordles to all be a variation of the same character.

In all honesty I suspect yordles are as cool as they are specifically because Riot has no idea what their doing with them.  All the other factions Riot has given us are pretty cliché with members all fitting in a narrow range.  Yordles on the other hand get to show a large range and diverse culture specifically because Riot has only a few basic ideas about them and everything else is up to individual design.

Iunno if it's specifically about Riot not knowing what to do with them, but I think that's a good point. Riot's not afraid of letting yordles be different, so we have strict and battle-ready Poppy and fun-loving, not-all-there Lulu as part of the same race, if not the same 'faction'.

Compare that to, say, Noxians, where everything has to fall under the theme of 'strength is everything!' Sure, everyone from Noxus is a variation upon that theme, but there's still he unifying idea of 'all Noxians think like this'. I'm not a big fan of that.

100% agree cannot up-vote this any harder. I love Bandle City and the Mothership. People may fall into categories but the variation is profound. Albert Einstein, Evil Knievil, and that fat mean chick at Wal-Mart who isn't shopping are ALL people. I don't see any reason Yordles should all be the same either. Plus their constant pursuit of "Getting the mothership repaired/operational/upgraded" explains a lot of their motivations.

Teemo: Scouting for raw materials, threats to the mothership. Also explains his sometimes mentioned mental instability as he is always alone and under great pressure. In addition he experiments with many poisons to attack his enemies with, and he needs to test them on something...

Tristana: Her cannon probably CAME from the mothership. She was likely an engineer who became distracted playing with it when she should have been putting it back on the ship after fixing it, and found out she had an in-born talent for ranged combat. A necessary skill when defending Bandle City from THE F'ING VOID AND SHADOW ISLES, not to mention Noxus!

Veigar: People go insane, why not Yordles? Maybe Veigar's job on the Mothership was to find out how to use magic to aid in its repair/upgrading. As Veigar delved deeper into something that isn't natural to Yordles his mind slowly cracked (You look into the Void, the Void looks back at you!), and it wasn't long before he was using other Yordles for his magic. This would EASILY explain why Yordles shy away from magic, Veigar would have convinced them it was unsafe for them to be messing with it!  Lulu is a loner and wouldn't have been exposed to Veigar's insanity, plus she's a little off herself.

Rumble: Simply the jealous type! Seeing Tristana every day while they worked on the Mothership together he just had to find a way to impress her. He didn't know how to do much, just what little he learned tinkering on the Mothership and what little he could understand of Heimerdinger's intense ravings about technology. He grabbed what little he could afford, he didn't have much left after caring for his dying mother/fixing up his storm-torn home/buying up enough tech for his cockpit/buying gifts for Tristana. Being that he isn't really brilliant, he used up his budget before he got to the legs and couldn't think of a cheap way to give his robot good traction until EUREKA! The plunger legs were born!

Lulu: Lulu was abandoned by bad parents. They left her in the forest to die, they were unable to bring themselves to care for a child and no other Yordle knew about her. Lulu was taken in by the magic of the forest (literally), and was raised by spirits and mythological forest beasts (possible tie-in to new Jax lore here!). She learned magic the way she learned everything else, it was a part of her constant daily reality. Other Yordles have no idea how to deal with her, she doesn't retain any part of their culture.

Heimerdinger: Heimerdinger is the Yordles premier mind. The Einstein or Stephen Hawking of his generation. Heimer quickly understood everything about the Mothership, including how it had nothing to do with the Yordles current predicaments. He tried to explain this to his fellow Yordles but like many geniuses Heimerdinger is misunderstood. He cannot fathom how to talk to people who aren't as smart as he is, and he quickly became unpopular with the other Yordles. Shunned and greatly disliked, Heimer left Bandle City to pursue the honing of his great mind in places where it would be appreciated.

I don't find it difficult to explain the Yordles or give them depth in the light of the Mothership, I really don't understand why Riot does. I'm stopping my list here because it's late and I'm tired. I'll do more if anybody wants.

They've already strongly hinted that they're demolishing essentially everything about Bandle City, including the Mothership, which CarnivalKnights specifically calls out above.

Scared, though? Whatever. They appear to have committed to spending the next several years destroying everything and laying new "foundations" for a League-less League of Legends (or "Runeterran") universe. I'm not going to put **[Factions](http://LeagueFactions.net)** or any other League lore projects of mine on hold while they do that, nor am I going to (e.g.) limit myself to what they've finished rewriting.

I'll still do my best to keep Factions close to Riot's wacky new League-less Runeterra project lore. I don't mind contrained writing: I enjoy the challenge of coming up with creative ways to wrap Factions lore around whatever new wrenches they throw into the works. Nonetheless, given their new "foundations" campaign, I'm going to start running up against the limits of my ability (or at least my desire) to be flexible.

For example, if they come through and declare that Bandle City is a goofy suburb of Piltover, or erase the weirder aspects of yordles (like their cultishness or their *intense* community ties) to make them generic fuzzballs, I'll probably have to just make that a point of divergence between the Factions universe and the Narrative universe.

They aren't losing any sleep over kicking us all out of Runeterra, or demolishing years of community lore to avoid hypothetical future "constraints", or severing their new lore's ties to the game itself in pursuit of some ambition to create a multimedia franchise. So I'm not going to be losing sleep over not showing much loyalty to their rather mercurial canon.

I think that's the point though, Yordles aren't a faction, and are a race of their own. It'd be like trying to say the "Human faction" and trying to tie them ALL down to a certain culture attributes.

You have all these archetypes of Yordles, all bound together by their racial characteristics and affinities, but beyond that, they have broken off into separate cultures of their own. 

The better part of your question that seems to bring up a GREAT point is the one about Bandle City. I see that group of yordles much like Hobbits, Kenders, or Halflings, Rural-esque tight-knit communities with a particular penchant for wanderlust and a innocent (relatively) outlook on life.

Lulu falls into the the racial part of being a Yordle, but being from The Glade (A dimension that bears striking resemblance to the Fey), she has her own values and experiences chiseled into that tiny yordle head. Like Carnival pointed out, she's from a place where changing shape and wild magic is very commonplace and that death isn't treated as seriously or morbid as it is elsewhere.

Lulu is not evil. In fact, I would argue she is the most innocent champion in LoL. This is the reason why she doesn't see the negative in Veigar. Pix, however, is another story.

**First, look at Lulu's kit:**

**Basic attack** - Required because it's part of the video game. 
*"Then only have Pix commit the attack!"* 
Problem there is Lulu loses Pix's attack when she shields an ally.

**Passive** - Pix adds his own attack to make sure the enemy gets hurt, in case Lulu goes easy on them.

**Q** - She's actually playing a game with Pix (intersect the beams of glitter!), but unbeknownst to her, the fae magic she shoots hurts others.

**W (on enemy)** - If you read Lulu's lore, you would know polymorphing was part of the game she played with the yordle children.

**E (on enemy)** - Pix is the one dealing damage, **not** Lulu.

**R** - More of Lulu playing around with her fae magic.

So it's pretty clear Pix is the one with a dark side, not Lulu. Pix is the true attacker. Lulu even says as one of her attack quotes, "Dust 'em, Pix!"

Pix was also the one who lured Lulu to the Glade. For what reason, it's currently unknown (officially). As stated in the lore, when Lulu first found Pix, he was **pretending** to be stuck in a bird house. That alone envelopes the event in mystery, and the mystery is what keeps Lulu believing Pix is her best friend who would never do her wrong.

**Now, the relationship with Veigar...**

Both Lulu and Veigar are Bandle City outcasts. That's already clear to everyone. It was what brought the two together, but what *exactly* created the attraction to Veigar?

After Lulu had joined the League, in one fateful match, she saw Veigar for the first time and asked her lane partner, Tristana, about him. She shared with Lulu his backstory and it brought upon a newfound feeling within her - a feeling of connection. Never before had she been able to feel she could be close to anyone in particular. Everyone was too plain and boring to her liking. Veigar, she felt, shared the same pain and grief she experienced. Perhaps, even, they were much more alike than she knew.
Despite her many failed attempts to establish a healthy friendship with Veigar (a.k.a. "Veiggie-poo"), Lulu sticks as close to him as she can without being blown apart by his vast magical power (yet isn't afraid of going for the occasional glomp), even though he could never find it within himself to kill the only yordle who sees the good in him.

**Of course Lulu cares about losing her entire family and past life**, but she does her best to block it out of her mind. She wants to play and be happy, not be moping and crying everyday. 
Remember, she isn't aware Pix was consciously responsible for it. She blames herself for staying in the Glade as long as she did, but of course not knowing prior about the time flow differences.

Lulu is schizophrenic. Veigar is the sociopath with Napoleon complex.
